SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Mr. James Kay Mrs. McKenzie

2. Your address: North Portal, Saskatchewan

3. Date: February 3, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   1867 Dundee Scotland

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   James Kay MacKenzie
   Machinist Engineer (Making Machinery)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Summer 1885
   (Immigrated to Canada from Scotland in 1882)

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Brandon, Manitoba 1882, as far as the railroad went. Migrated to Saskatchewan from Manitoba by wagon. Resided there for about two years in Seattle, Washington between the years 1882-1884.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
   I was in my teens when I came to Sask.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   1. I had a sister Mrs. Harry Burton (my mind was Burton previously was Mrs. Jack Burton until his death) living at Brandon.
   2. Came to Sask. Homestead in 1885 with my wife & first child Ethel.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    1. The relatives were out here & he wanted to come.
    2. Robert MacKenzie was a schoolmate in the United States who told me about Canada.

   a. To find work

   a. Through friends
   b. Through newspapers

   Be very brief in your answers.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They agreed with it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   My brother Tom MacKenzie came at the same time as myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Came by steamboat. They also had sails on the boat as well in certain positions.
   (2) Journey west by rail to Brandon.
   (3) On coming to Saskatchewan by way of Brandon was the farthest extent of the railroad.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
   Some Sioux Indians.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   North Partal & Homestead. There was no town here then so they had to go to Brandon South for supplies. The mail had come that far.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Settled two miles from what is now known as North Partal in a desert, but fairly promising. There had been some snow, too.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Just North Partal.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   (1) In Scotland - 2 years as an apprentice in a machine shop.
   (2) But at Seattle worked in Bank of Contractors.
   (3) Saskatchewan Farm.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My friend Mr. Smith thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I traveled with my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

- Came by train from Winnipeg.
- Came by car from Edmonton.
- Came by bus from Calgary.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, accidents or other excitement etc.)

Meeting with Indians near Medicine Hat.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

North Battleford.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I settled in North Battleford.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Just North Battleford.

18. How did you make a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

- Worked as a farmer.
- Worked as a laborer.
- Worked as a miner.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

I wrote when I took the nation.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Elizabeth Alberta Waddington

only relatives

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

① On moving I had from Manitoba they got caught in a snow storm (in upper end of Hastings) they had to stay several days at what is now Hilda, Sask. The snow filled the river, the chickens were in vanity their heads were sticking out.
② Had terrible prairie fires and large in the area,
and ③ The worst failure came through on this season after an their trail was near by.
④ That's how a lot of them on the grown are don't have much.

① Had church 3 miles Eastside church.
② Didn't visit friends and returning from town.
③ Way out of town, then back to buggy.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

- Myself, J. K. MacKenzie was Councilor for over years in Macfield Municipality, and the first one of you ever put a new organization here at Macfield (75-84).
- Son H. W. MacKenzie was Town Crier for Macfield Municipality.
- Son Ken MacKenzie is now Councilor here for 60 years.
- J. K. MacKenzie was trustee of School District 1899.
